author: Sophie Elsworth
title: Simple ways to slash your household bills
text:
Video Image Cut the cost of running your home 1:58 Five simple ways to cut down household bills
September 29th 2015 22 days ago /video/video.news.com.au/Lifestyle/ Abigail Koch says rounding up or guessing the value of your home and contents for insurance can often leave you out of pocket.
Sophie Elsworth THE rising cost of living continues to put pressure on households with necessities from rent or mortgage costs to the weekly grocery bill on the rise.
While there’s nothing you can do about inflation, your domestic budget could be long overdue for a review of the way you spend money.
We’ve quizzed the experts on those costs you can’t escape and asked them how you can trim the fat on the necessities so you have more to spend on life’s pleasures.
RENT/MORTGAGE
MOST of us are not lucky enough to live mortgage or rent free, so working out a way to cut these costs is a good place to start.
Financial expert and founder of advisory business Wealth Enhancers Sarah Riegelhuth says if you have a home loan the best place to start is to review your borrowing and make sure you have an offset account.
Tuck away any extra cash you have into this account which runs as an everyday transaction account and it will instantly help diminish your interest costs.
For example, if you have a $300,000 home loan and $10,000 in an offset account, you only pay interest on $290,000.
Riegelhuth also advises comparing your interest rates to other banks by using financial comparison sites every three to five years.
If you rent, you may have to make sacrifices to curb weekly costs. This may mean house sharing instead of living alone, bunking back down with the parents or even house sitting.
Whether you rent or pay a mortgage there are ways to cut back on costs. Source: AAP
PHONE/INTERNET
YOU won’t find many people without a phone in the house, whether it be a mobile or landline or a connection to the internet.
Riegelhuth says this is an ever-changing space and all telco users should take an active approach to hunting around for more competitive deals.
“The phone companies and internet providers are making new deals all the time so I think it’s important to look at that when your current provider’s plan is up and see what else is available,’’ she says.
“These days do you really need a home phone anymore? You may even find it’s enough to have your mobile and stream data from that at home depending on your usage.”
It’s also worth considering bundling your internet and mobile services — this will help cut costs.
Comparison sites such as whistleout.com.au can be useful for shopping for deals.
Sarah Riegelhuth advises an active approach to hunting around for more competitive deals. Picture: Mark Stewart Source: News Corp Australia
UTILITIES
Comparethemarket.com.au ’s spokeswoman Abigail Koch says less than one in five Australian households bother to switch their energy plans each year to nab a better deal.
“Switching is simple, you still receive exactly the same energy supply without having to disconnect. The main change you’ll see will be in the billing paperwork,’’ she says as the new supplier will do all the hard work of switching for you.
Consider opting into monthly, rather than quarterly, billing to spread the pain and make a conscious effort to switch appliances off at the wall; this can save you more than $100 a year.
GROCERIES
The fewer trips to the supermarket you make in a week, the better.
So do a weekly menu plan then make a shopping list and stick to it. Stay away from the supermarket when you’re hungry; this will make you want to buy more without you even realising it.
Riegelhuth also suggests buying items such as boxes of fruit and vegetables direct from suppliers that can be delivered to your front door.
“Structure your shopping, for example if I buy a box of fruit and vegetables every week I just have to use what’s in it because I don’t want to throw any of it away.”
FIND A HIGH INTEREST SAVINGS ACCOUNT
Abigail Koch says rounding up or guessing the value of your home and contents for insurance can often leave you out of pocket. Source: News Corp Australia
INSURANCE
Don’t be tempted to just sign up to the cheapest policy possible, this could hurt you when you make a claim.
Koch says be sure to sign up to insurance that is tailored to suit you and make sure you are thorough in documenting your home and contents information.
“Try not to over or underestimate the value of your home’s contents,’’ she says.
“Rounding up or guessing can often leave you out of pocket whether it’s through higher than necessary monthly insurance premiums or a lower than expected payout when you make a claim.”
